questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

 

Pacinian corpuscles are specialized nerve endings located deep within the skin and other tissues. They are highly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, making them particularly adept at detecting fast vibrations. These receptors are crucial for perceiving textures and fine details through vibration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ruffini - Fine touch: This is incorrect because Ruffini endings are mechanoreceptors that detect skin stretch, not fine touch. They are deeper in the skin and contribute to the sensation of skin deformation, which is associated with stretch rather than fine touch.

 

Option C. Meissner - Stretch: This is incorrect because Meissner's corpuscles are responsible for detecting light touch, not stretch. They are located near the surface of the skin and are sensitive to changes in texture and slow vibrations.

 

Option D. Merkel - Slow vibration: This is incorrect because Merkel cells are associated with fine touch and two-point discrimination, not slow vibrations. They are particularly sensitive to edges, points, and textures, which aids in tasks like reading Braille.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRPV1 Channel

 

Fig: Signal transduction in taste receptors: Salt and sour tastes are mediated via the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This receptor has two subunits (a and g), each crossing the membrane twice, resulting in intracellular N and C termini (NT, CT). Salt is sensed following Na+ movement; sour is mediated by movement of H+. Sweet, bitter, and umami tastes are sensed via G-protein-coupled receptors that span the membrane seven times and have varying lengths of CT and NT (represented as ribbon structures). Sweet tastes are detected by the T1R2 and T1R3 families, bitter and umami tastes are detected by the T2R family and mGluR4, respectively.

 

Fig: Receptors on nociceptive unmyelinated nerve terminals in the skin. Nociceptive stimuli (eg, heat) can activate some receptors directly due to transduction of the stimulus energy by receptors (eg, transient receptor potential (TRP) channel TRPV1) or indirectly by activation of TRP channels on keratinocytes (eg, TRPV3). Nociceptors (eg, mechanoreceptors) can also be activated by the release of intermediate molecules (eg, ATP), ASIC, acid-sensitive ion channel; P2X, ionotropic purinoceptor, P2Y, G-protein-coupled purinergic receptor.

 

Sour taste is primarily mediated by the detection of H+ ions, which are present in acidic substances like citric acid. These H+ ions activate ion channels rather than G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Specifically, the TRPV1 (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid Receptor Type 1) channel and acid-sensitive ion channels are involved in mediating the sour taste. These channels open in response to the presence of H+ ions, allowing the ions to enter the taste cells, which leads to the perception of a sour taste.

 

Metabotropic receptors, which involve GPCRs, mediate other taste modalities like sweet, bitter, and umami but are not involved in sour taste. The GPCR T1R1 and T1R3 are specifically involved in the sweet and umami taste pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabotropic Receptor: This type of receptor is associated with GPCRs and mediates taste sensations like sweet, bitter, and umami. It is not involved in sour taste, which is mediated by ion channels.

 

Option C. GPCR T1R1: This receptor is part of the GPCR family and is involved in detecting umami (savory) tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Option D. GPCR T1R3: This receptor is also a part of the GPCR family and contributes to the detection of sweet and umami tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sour taste is mediated by the activation of ion channels, particularly the TRPV1 channel and acid-sensitive ion channels, in response to H+ ions from acidic substances

questions.text: A 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with a 2-week history of rapidly increasing swelling on his jaw, recurrent nosebleeds, weight loss, and generalized fatigue. Physical examination of the neck reveals firm, nontender lymph nodes. The mass is biopsied, the image is shown below. Which of the following best describes the genomic structure of the most likely causative virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Double-stranded linear DNA

 

  • This patient’s presentation, including rapid swelling of lymph nodes, recurrent nosebleeds, weight loss, and fatigue, is concerning for lymphoma, particularly Burkitt lymphoma. 
  • Burkitt lymphoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), a virus with a double-stranded linear DNA genome. 
  • EBV is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of several lymphoproliferative diseases, including Burkitt lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Double-stranded circular DNA: This is characteristic of certain viruses like the herpesvirus family (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus), but Epstein-Barr virus specifically has a linear double-stranded DNA genome, not circular.

 

Option C. Double-stranded linear RNA: Double-stranded RNA viruses are found in families like reoviruses, but they are not associated with Burkitt lymphoma or the Epstein-Barr virus.

 

Option D. Single-stranded linear RNA: Single-stranded RNA viruses (e.g., influenza virus, HIV) are not associated with Burkitt lymphoma, which is linked to EBV, a DNA virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely causative virus for this patient’s symptoms is Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), which has a double-stranded linear DNA genome. 
  • EBV is associated with Burkitt lymphoma and other lymphoproliferative disorders.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female is undergoing tubal ligation, and the procedure illustrated in the image is performed. Which of the following methods best describes the surgical technique used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parkland method

 

  • The image shows the Parkland method of tubal ligation, a widely used technique for permanent female sterilization. 
  • In this method, a segment of the fallopian tube is tied on both ends and excised. The procedure involves:
    1. Grasping the isthmic portion of the fallopian tube.
    2. Placing two ligatures (sutures) around the tube at a specific site.
    3. Excising the segment of the fallopian tube between the ligatures.
  • The Parkland method is effective, safe, and minimizes the risk of fistula formation since only a small portion of the tube is removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pomeroy method: In the Pomeroy method, the fallopian tube is tied and a loop is formed, which is then excised. It is a simpler procedure but less commonly performed compared to the Parkland method.

 

Option C. Irving method: The Irving method involves tying the fallopian tube, then burying the proximal end in the uterine wall and the distal end in the broad ligament. It is not depicted in this image.

 

Option D. Uchida method: The Uchida method involves injecting the mesosalpinx with saline to dissect the tube away from its mesentery before ligation and excision. This is not the method shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Parkland method of tubal ligation involves ligating and excising a segment of the fallopian tube to provide permanent sterilization. 
  • It is a common and effective surgical technique with a low risk of complications, making it a preferred method in many cases.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents due to fatigue, easy bruising, and frequent nosebleeds for 2 weeks. On physical examination, the child appears pale with scattered petechiae. Laboratory studies show:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.9 g/dL

 

Platelet count: 21,000/mm³

 

Leukocyte count: 15,500/mm³

 

A bone marrow aspirate reveals the findings shown in the image below. The cells are positive for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and express CD19 and CD10. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Precursor B-cell leukemia 

 

  • The child's symptoms (fatigue, bruising, nosebleeds), laboratory findings (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytosis), and bone marrow aspirate indicate acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
  • Positivity for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) and expression of CD19 and CD10 are characteristic markers of precursor B-cell ALL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Precursor T-cell leukemia: Precursor T-cell leukemia expresses markers like CD3 and lacks CD19.

 

Option C. Mature B-cell leukemia and D. Mature T-cell leukemia: Mature B-cell or T-cell leukemias would not express TdT.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for recurrent nosebleeds. The mother reports that the boy has had five nosebleeds within the past 2 weeks, each lasting between 15 and 20 minutes. The patient was born at term and has been hospitalized twice for pneumonia treatment. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient is at the 8th percentile for height and the 30th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a small, thin child with two flat, dark brown areas of hyperpigmentation across the upper back and a similar discoloration on the left buttock. There is bilateral esotropia. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 9.3 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume of 107 um3, leukocyte count of 3800/mm3, and platelet count of 46,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA crosslink repair

 

The patient most likely has Fanconi anemia, caused by defects in DNA crosslink repair. It presents with pancytopenia, congenital anomalies, café-au-lait spots, and growth retardation.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Mutation in WAS protein: Causes Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome; features include small platelets, eczema, and recurrent infections, but not congenital anomalies like café-au-lait spots.

 

Option C. Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia: Usually presents with blast cells on peripheral smear, rapid onset, and bone pain; not typical congenital anomalies.

 

Option D. Post Viral Autoimmune reaction: Usually causes isolated cytopenias transiently, not multiple congenital anomalies or chronic pancytopenia.

choices.text: Rifampicin resistance with both KatG and inhA mutation

questions.text: Which of the following is an inclusion criterion for the shorter bedaquiline regimen in the treatment of tuberculosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Rifampicin-resistant but fluoroquinolone-sensitive TB

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 2 months of worsening fatigue and persistent lower back pain that is aggravated by movement. Physical examination shows pallor and tenderness over the lower spine. Radiographic imaging reveals lytic bone lesions. Laboratory findings include:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.5 g/dL

Serum creatinine: 2.8 mg/dL

Serum calcium: 11.0 mg/dL

 

Urine dipstick is negative for protein, but 24-hour urine protein quantification shows elevated protein levels. Urine electrophoresis is most likely to detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lambda light chains

 

  • The patient's presentation of fatigue, anemia, back pain with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal dysfunction is classic for multiple myeloma.
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell malignancy producing excess monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains (either kappa or lambda).
  • These free light chains are filtered by the kidney and appear in the urine as Bence Jones proteins.
  • Urine electrophoresis in multiple myeloma typically detects excess free light chains (kappa or lambda) rather than intact immunoglobulins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gamma heavy chains: Gamma heavy chains are seen in heavy chain diseases, which are rare.

 

Option B. Immunoglobulin G and C. Immunoglobulin M: Immunoglobulin G or M refers to intact immunoglobulins, which typically show up in serum electrophoresis rather than urine.

questions.text: What is a patient's urine analysis most likely to show if they have hematuria and hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isomorphic RBCs

 

  • Hypercalciuria predisposes to nephrolithiasis, which causes non-glomerular hematuria.
  • This presents as isomorphic RBCs on urinalysis.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. RBC casts: Suggest glomerulonephritis, not stone disease.

 

Option C. Nephrotic proteinuria: Not related to hypercalciuria.

 

Option D. Eosinophiluria: Seen in drug-induced interstitial nephritis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain, redness, and swelling around a laceration on his left leg that he sustained 5 days ago. The wound was cleaned and dressed at the time of injury. On examination, there is erythema surrounding the wound and purulent discharge when pressure is applied. Which of the following cytokines is most likely responsible for the accumulation of pus at the site of this wound?
Identify the enzyme not involved in cholesterol biosynthesis.
Which of the following enzymes is produced in increased amounts than normal in the liver of a patient with lead toxicity?

choices.text: Cannot be separated from each other on Electrophoresis.

questions.text: Which is correct about isoenzymes?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Catalyse the same reaction.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a syncopal episode. He has had no chest pain or dyspnea but he has constipation of recent onset. He was hospitalized 2 weeks ago for atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and was discharged home with oral medications after appropriate management. Medical history is also significant for hypertension and severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease requiring home supplemental oxygen. ECG shows new-onset second-degree atrioventricular block. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of his current condition?

A 38-year-old patient presents with sudden-onset facial weakness and drooping on one side of the face. The patient also complains of drooling while eating, likely due to weakness in a muscle marked in green. Which of the following structures does not pierce the involved muscle?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Buccal branch of facial nerve

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to depression. Since breaking up with her boyfriend last month, she has been extremely sad and has difficulty getting out of bed. She describes sleeping 16 hours a day, increased appetite, a 4.5-kg weight gain, low energy, decreased concentration, and loss of interest in socializing with her friends and family. The patient had 2 similar episodes at age 23 and 27. She also describes brief periods in the past, lasting several days, when she was uncharacteristically confident and optimistic, successfully juggled 3 part-time jobs, and felt well rested and energetic despite sleeping only 3-4 hours a night. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother, who is concerned about his language development. She says, "I know that children speak at different ages and he is still young, but I am concerned that his speech isn't progressing and that he needs to interact with other children more. His day care teacher says that he is shy and sits in a corner playing with his favorite truck. We have also been busy with a recent move and have not given him as much attention, which doesn't help. The patient's birth history, medical history, and audiology screening are unremarkable. In the examination room, the patient sits in a corner, avoiding eye contact with the doctor. He does not respond to his name. He makes occasional grunting sounds but says no fully formed words. When his mother tries to take his truck away, he begins screaming and pulls it back. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 3-month-old boy is brought to the OPD for follow-up due to a unilateral cleft lip and palate. The patient has been doing well, feeding with specialized bottle nipples and is gaining weight. As part of his multidisciplinary care, the parents are told that he will need to be monitored for ear infections and hearing loss. This is because the patient most likely has dysfunction of which of the following muscles?

A patient diagnosed with type 2 neurofibromatosis was referred to the Department of Otorhinolaryngology for hearing rehabilitation after excision of bilateral acoustic neuromas. The surgery notes mentioned that the 8th nerve was severed during the surgery. After further evaluation, a decision to insert an implant to aid hearing was made. Where will the implant be placed?
All of the following form boundaries of quadrangular space except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraspinatus

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical space in the posterior shoulder region that allows passage of the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery.

 

Its boundaries are:

 

  • Superior: Teres minor
  • Inferior: Teres major
  • Medial: Long head of triceps
  • Lateral: Surgical neck of humerus

 

 

Supraspinatus does not take part in forming this space. It is located superiorly in the supraspinous fossa and is related to the suprascapular notch, not the quadrangular space.

questions.text: At what cervical dilation is an epidural typically administered during labor to manage pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3–4 cm

 

  • Epidural analgesia is commonly administered during the active phase of labor, typically when cervical dilation is around 3–4 cm. 
  • At this stage, the labor is established, and the patient can benefit from pain relief without significant risk of slowing labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1–2 cm: This is during the latent phase, and epidural administration at this stage is less common due to concerns about prolonging labor.

 

Option C. 5–6 cm: While epidurals can still be given, they are typically initiated earlier during the active phase.

 

Option D. 7–8 cm: This is during advanced labor, and though an epidural can be provided, it may not be as beneficial or practical at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidural analgesia is typically administered during the active phase of labor, at 3–4 cm cervical dilation, to provide effective pain relief while minimizing the risk of labor delay.

questions.text: What does Chopart’s injury involves?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints

 

  • Chopart's injury specifically affects the midfoot and involves damage to the Talonavicular and Calcaneocuboid joints. 
  • These two joints form the Chopart joint complex, which connects the talus (with the navicular and calcaneus bones. 
  • Injury to these joints often occurs due to high-impact trauma or fractures, disrupting foot stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tibiotalar and subtalar joints: The Tibiotalar joint and the subtalar joint are both located in the ankle, not the midfoot. These joints are involved in movements like plantarflexion, dorsiflexion, and inversion/eversion, but they are not affected in Chopart’s injury.

 

Option C. Metatarsophalangeal joints: The Metatarsophalangeal joints are located at the base of the toes and are responsible for flexing and extending the toes. While these joints are important for walking, they are not the focus of a Chopart's injury, which specifically involves the midfoot, not the toes.

 

Option D. Proximal and distal interphalangeal joints: The proximal and distal interphalangeal joints are found in the toes and allow for the bending of the toe segments. These joints are involved in toe movements like flexion and extension, but Chopart’s injury affects the midfoot joints (Talonavicular and Calcaneocuboid joints), not the toe joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints are the most commonly affected in Chopart's injury. 
  • The others describe joints in the foot and ankle that are not involved in this specific injury.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with limp. X-ray of the pelvis was taken. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibrous dysplasia

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disorder in which normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, resulting in bone weakening and deformities. 
  • It can affect one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic). The pelvis, femur, and ribs are commonly involved. 
  • It can occur at any age, but it is more commonly diagnosed in childhood or adolescence.
  • X-ray of fibrous dysplasia typically shows a "ground-glass" appearance or "café au lait" spots. 

 

 

  • The bone is often expanded or deformed, and there may be cortical thinning or bowing. 
  • The affected bone may appear irregular and weakened, making it prone to fractures.
  • Pain, deformities, and limping due to fractures or bone weakness are common. 
  • Depending on the location of the lesion, the individual may have functional limitations, such as difficulty walking.
  • Bone biopsy can be done to confirm the diagnosis, which will show fibrous tissue replacing normal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s Disease: Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. It involves excessive bone resorption followed by abnormal bone formation, leading to weakened bones that are prone to fractures. Paget’s disease typically affects older adults, and it is rare in individuals under 40. The disease commonly involves the pelvis, spine, femur, and skull. Paget's disease can show "cotton wool" appearance (patchy sclerosis), bowing of bones, and enlarged bones. In severe cases, it can lead to deformities and fractures. It may present with joint pain and deformities leading to difficulty with walking or limping, but this is rare in young people. Paget's disease can be confirmed with increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels.

 

 

Option B. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell that produces antibodies. It leads to the formation of multiple tumors in bone marrow, which can cause bone destruction, pain, fractures, and anemia. The disease is uncommon in young individuals and is typically diagnosed in people over 65 years old. In multiple myeloma, X-rays often show punched-out lesions (areas of bone destruction), and the bones may appear weakened. There may also be diffuse osteopenia (reduced bone density). Bone pain, fatigue, weakness, fractures, and in some cases, kidney problems. However, limping as an initial presenting symptom would be unusual. Multiple myeloma is diagnosed through blood tests (like serum protein electrophoresis) and bone marrow biopsy, along with imaging studies.

 

 

Option C. Osteopoikilosis: Osteopoikilosis is a rare, benign bone condition characterized by multiple, round or oval-shaped bone islands (sclerotic foci) within the bones. These are usually found incidentally on X-rays and are typically asymptomatic. It is a congenital condition, and affected individuals usually do not experience any symptoms. The key feature of osteopoikilosis is the presence of multiple small, well-circumscribed areas of increased bone density, often described as "bone islands." These are most commonly seen in the pelvis, femur, and other long bones. Typically, osteopoikilosis is asymptomatic and does not cause any pain or functional impairment. It is generally found incidentally during radiological investigations for other reasons. The diagnosis is based on the characteristic appearance of bone islands on X-ray. There is no need for further clinical investigation unless complications (like fractures) occur, which is very rare.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paget's disease is unlikely due to the patient's young age.
  • Multiple myeloma is unlikely because it's very rare in young individuals and typically presents with systemic symptoms.
  • Osteopoikilosis is unlikely as it is asymptomatic and would not cause limping.
  • Fibrous dysplasia is the most likely diagnosis due to its characteristic appearance on X-ray and its association with bone pain, deformities, and limping in young individuals.

questions.text: An 80-year-old male's autopsy reveals ventricular thickening and abnormal aggregations of protein filaments arranged in beta-pleated sheets within the ventricular walls. Bone marrow examination shows no evidence of plasma cell dyscrasia. The abnormal protein aggregations are most likely composed of which of the following?
Identify Roenne’s nasal step in visual field testing from the images shown:

choices.text: Exploratory laparotomy, gastrotomy, and oversewing of the tear

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman with a history of unstable angina complains of hematemesis after retching and vomiting following a night of binge drinking. Which of the following is the next recommended step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Coronary artery blood flow and ischemia.
Myocardial perfusion during exercise and rest.
Function of the ventricles, particularly the ejection fraction.
Evaluation of valvular function and regurgitation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with a history of heart failure and chemotherapy for breast cancer is evaluated using a MUGA scan to assess cardiac function. What specific aspect of heart function is primarily evaluated by a MUGA scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Function of the ventricles, particularly the ejection fraction.

 

  • A MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan is primarily used to evaluate the function of the ventricles, particularly assessing the ejection fraction, which is critical in the management of heart failure. 
  • This test helps assess the extent of myocardial damage and cardiac dysfunction, especially in patients with a history of chemotherapy (like anthracyclines) that may be cardiotoxic.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Coronary artery blood flow and ischemia: Incorrect. A MUGA scan does not evaluate coronary artery flow but focuses on ventricular function.
 

Option B. Myocardial perfusion during exercise and rest: Incorrect. MUGA scan is used to evaluate ventricular function, not myocardial perfusion during stress.
 

Option D. Evaluation of valvular function and regurgitation: Incorrect. A MUGA scan does not assess valvular function, but instead focuses on ventricular ejection fraction.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The MUGA scan primarily evaluates ventricular function and ejection fraction, which is crucial in diagnosing and managing heart failure.

questions.text: Which one of the following amino acids is most likely to be found in the transmembrane region of a protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leucine

 

  • The transmembrane region of a protein is typically embedded within the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. 
  • The key characteristic of this region is that it is hydrophobic in nature. 
  • Amino acids with hydrophobic side chains are more likely to be found in this region, as they can interact favorably with the hydrophobic interior of the lipid bilayer.
  • Leucine is a hydrophobic amino acid, making it well-suited for insertion into the transmembrane region. 
  • It is classified as a nonpolar amino acid with a hydrophobic side chain, which allows it to integrate into the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysine: Lysine is a positively charged (basic) amino acid, making it hydrophilic rather than hydrophobic. Hydrophilic amino acids are more likely to be found on the outer surface of the membrane, interacting with the aqueous environment, rather than being buried in the transmembrane region.

 

Option B. Arginine: Arginine is also a positively charged (basic) amino acid, which makes it hydrophilic. Like lysine, it is more likely to be located on the surface of the protein in contact with the aqueous environment rather than being embedded in the hydrophobic interior of the lipid bilayer.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is a negatively charged (acidic) amino acid, making it hydrophilic as well. Similar to lysine and arginine, it is more likely to be found on the surface of the protein, interacting with water, rather than within the hydrophobic transmembrane region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amino acids with hydrophobic side chains, such as leucine, isoleucine, valine, and phenylalanine, are typically found in the transmembrane regions of membrane proteins. 
  • These hydrophobic amino acids interact favorably with the lipid bilayer, whereas hydrophilic amino acids (like lysine, arginine, and aspartate) are found on the exterior of the membrane, interacting with the aqueous environment.

choices.text: A Type I error has occurred because the null hypothesis is rejected with a P-value less than α.
The P-value is greater than the significance level, meaning the null hypothesis should be rejected.
The Type II error rate is at its maximum, indicating no significant difference.
The P-value is less than α, so the null hypothesis is rejected, and the result is statistically significant.

questions.text: A study reports a P-value of 0.03 and declares the results statistically significant with a significance level (α) set at 0.05. Which of the following statements is true based on this information?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The P-value is less than α, so the null hypothesis is rejected, and the result is statistically significant.

 

  • Since the P-value (0.03) is less than the significance level (α = 0.05), the null hypothesis is rejected, and the results are declared statistically significant. 
  • This does not necessarily mean the treatment is effective, but that there is a statistical difference according to the set threshold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A Type I error has occurred because the null hypothesis is rejected with a P-value less than α: Incorrect. A Type I error would occur if the null hypothesis is true, but is incorrectly rejected, not simply by having a P-value less than α.

 

Option B. The P-value is greater than the significance level, meaning the null hypothesis should be rejected: Incorrect. Since the P-value is less than α, the null hypothesis should be rejected, not accepted.

 

Option C. The Type II error rate is at its maximum, indicating no significant difference: Incorrect. Type II error occurs when the null hypothesis is false, but is not rejected, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A P-value less than α indicates that the result is statistically significant, meaning the null hypothesis is rejected.

questions.text: A healthcare facility is conducting screening for breast cancer using a two-step process. First, all women are tested using a mammography (test A), followed by an ultrasound (test B) for those who are positive on mammography. If the sensitivity of mammography is 90% and that of ultrasound is 85%, what is the combined sensitivity of the two tests when used in series?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 76.5%

 

  • The combined sensitivity of two tests in series is calculated by multiplying the sensitivity of both tests:
    Combined sensitivity = Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B) = 0.90 × 0.85 = 0.765, or 76.5%.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Tests in Series & Parallel:

choices.text: The BCG vaccine has high efficacy in preventing pulmonary TB in adults.
The BCG vaccine provides 80% efficacy against miliary TB and meningeal TB in children.
The BCG vaccine is effective for lifetime against all forms of TB.
The BCG vaccine has zero efficacy against meningeal TB.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the efficacy of the BCG vaccine is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The BCG vaccine provides 80% efficacy against miliary TB and meningeal TB in children.

 

  • The BCG vaccine has a median efficacy of 50% but offers 0-80% efficacy in preventing miliary TB and meningeal TB in children, particularly in regions with high TB burden. 
  • It does not provide protection against pulmonary TB.

 

Other Options:

Option A. The BCG vaccine has high efficacy in preventing pulmonary TB in adults: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine has limited efficacy for pulmonary TB.
 

Option C. The BCG vaccine is effective for lifetime against all forms of TB: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine does not provide lifetime protection and has variable efficacy.


Option D. The BCG vaccine has zero efficacy against meningeal TB: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine is effective in preventing meningeal TB in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCG vaccine provides limited protection against pulmonary TB but is effective against miliary TB and meningeal TB in children.

choices.text: 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol
25% reduction in premature mortality from NCDs
30% reduction in the mean population intake of sodium
20% relative reduction in physical inactivity

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the voluntary global NCD targets set by WHO for 2025?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20% relative reduction in physical inactivity

 

  • The WHO target for 2025 includes a 10% reduction in physical inactivity in the population, not 20%. 
  • The other targets, including alcohol reduction, sodium intake reduction, and premature mortality reduction, are accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol: Alcohol reduction is indeed a 10% relative reduction target.

 

Option B. 25% reduction in premature mortality from NCDs: A 25% reduction in premature mortality from NCDs is a core target.

 

Option C. 30% reduction in the mean population intake of sodium: The 30% reduction in sodium intake is another of WHO's goals for 2025.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is impaired.
Pancreatic protease secretion is insufficient to release vitamin B12 from haptocorrin.
Haptocorrin binding to vitamin B12 is defective, leading to reduced transport.
Intrinsic factor is not secreted, preventing B12 binding in the stomach.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female who has had a history of Crohn's disease for many years, underwent ileal resection, now presents with megaloblastic anemia despite adequate dietary intake of vitamin B12. Which of the following steps in the absorption of vitamin B12 is most likely disrupted due to her ileal resection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is impaired.

 

  • In patients with ileal resection due to Crohn's disease, cubilin receptors on ileal enterocytes are lost. 
  • These receptors are essential for the endocytosis of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex, which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. 
  • Without these receptors, the complex cannot be absorbed, leading to B12 deficiency and resultant megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pancreatic protease secretion is insufficient to release vitamin B12 from haptocorrin: Incorrect. Pancreatic proteases aid in the release of B12 from haptocorrin in the duodenum, but their dysfunction does not directly impair the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex absorption in the ileum.

 

Option C. Haptocorrin bindingto vitamin B12 is defective, leading to reduced transport: Incorrect. Haptocorrin binding occurs in the stomach and aids initial B12 transport, but it is the cubilin receptors in the ileum that mediate the complex's final absorption.

 

Option D. Intrinsic factor is not secreted, preventing B12 binding in the stomach: Incorrect. Intrinsic factor is usually present, and the problem is in the absorption of the complex in the ileum, not its initial binding in the stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ileal resection disrupts cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis, impairing the absorption of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex and leading to B12 deficiency.

choices.text: Endothelial cell proliferation associated with a viral infection
Fibroblast proliferation in response to trauma
Malignant vascular proliferation due to immune dysregulation

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a painful mass in his thumb that has been bothering him for several weeks. The pain is described as a sharp, localized sensation. Histology slide is given below. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the tumor's origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arteriovenous structure involved in thermoregulation

 

  • Glomus tumors originate from the modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies, which are specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. 
  • These structures help regulate temperature by controlling blood flow to the extremities, and the tumor arises due to abnormal growth of these structures.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Endothelial cell proliferation associated with a viral infection: Incorrect. Endothelial cell proliferation is seen in conditions like hemangiomas or Kaposi’s sarcoma, not in glomus tumors.

 

Option C. Fibroblast proliferationin response to trauma: Incorrect. Fibroblast proliferation occurs in fibromas or scar tissue formation, not in glomus tumors.

 

Option D. Malignant vascular proliferation due to immune dysregulation: Incorrect. Glomus tumors are benign, not malignant, and do not result from immune dysregulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glomus tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies, specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation.

questions.text:
Which of the following combinations regarding ERAS protocol is correct?

 

  1. Mechanical bowel preparation should be avoided
  2. Early ambulation within 24 hours
  3. Consume clear fluids up to 4 hours prior to surgery
  4. IV fluids are continued until discharge
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 2 only

 

Statement 1: Correct - ERAS advocates avoiding mechanical bowel prep

 

Statement 2: Correct - Early ambulation within 24 hours

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 3: False - Consume clear fluids up to 2 hours prior to surgery

 

Statement 4: False - IV fluids should be discontinued within 24 hours

 

Educational Objective: 

 

ERAS Protocol (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery Protocol)

choices.text: The gallstone is causing a complete obstruction of the bile duct.
There is a small amount of bile behind the gallstone.
The gallstone is blocking the X-ray during a radiograph.
The gallstone is absorbing sound waves and preventing their passage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with right upper quadrant pain and is suspected to have chronic cholecystitis with gallstones. During the ultrasound, the Wall-Echo-Shadow (WES) sign is noted. What does the presence of the acoustic shadowing distal to the gallstone indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The gallstone is absorbing sound waves and preventing their passage.

 

  • Acoustic shadowing occurs when a solid structure, like a gallstone, absorbs or reflects sound waves, preventing them from passing through and creating a shadow on the ultrasound image. 
  • This is a hallmark of gallstone presence and is used to identify the stone and its relationship with surrounding structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The gallstone is causing a complete obstruction of the bile duct: Incorrect. Acoustic shadowing does not indicate bile duct obstruction, but rather the presence of a gallstone.

 

Option B. There is a small amount of bile behind the gallstone: Incorrect. The presence of acoustic shadowing suggests the stone is blocking the passage of sound waves, not the amount of bile.

 

Option C. The gallstone is blocking the X-ray during a radiograph: Incorrect. Acoustic shadowing is observed on ultrasound, not X-ray, which uses different principles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acoustic shadowing on ultrasound occurs when a gallstone absorbs sound waves, preventing them from passing through and producing a shadow on the image.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man, Rajesh from Mumbai, visits the clinic for routine follow-up after undergoing pneumatic dilation for esophageal achalasia. He reports significant improvement in dysphagia and nocturnal regurgitation. His medical history includes borderline hypertension and an anxiety disorder. He previously smoked (5 pack-years) and has a family history of Sjögren’s disease and lymphoma. He is currently taking omeprazole and clonazepam.

 

On examination:

 

  • BP: 135/85 mmHg
  • Pulse: 67/min
  • BMI: 30 kg/m²
  • Systemic examination: Unremarkable

 

Over the next 10 years, which of the following conditions is he at the highest risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • Achalasia is a chronic motility disorder that leads to the accumulation of food and stasis in the esophagus, which increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) over time. 
  • The constant irritation and inflammation from retained food, along with bacterial overgrowth, predispose the esophageal mucosa to dysplasia and subsequent malignancy.
  • Achalasia-associated SCC risk: 30-fold increase compared to the general population
  • Peak risk: 10-20 years after diagnosis
  • Typical location: Mid to distal esophagus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrosing mediastinitis: A rare condition caused by granulomatous inflammation, often due to Histoplasma capsulatum infection, not achalasia.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: More likely in patients with chronic immunosuppression or autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjögren’s disease). Rajesh's family history of lymphoma does not significantly elevate his personal risk.

 

Option C. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis typically occurs in infants due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, unrelated to achalasia or its treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with achalasia have a significantly increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma due to prolonged food stasis, bacterial overgrowth, and chronic mucosal irritation. Long-term surveillance with periodic endoscopy is crucial in monitoring for early malignant changes.

choices.text: Antinuclear antibody and double-stranded DNA antibody assay

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of left knee pain and swelling. He has no prior joint pain, trauma, fever, rash, or systemic symptoms. His medical history includes seasonal allergies, and he takes loratadine as needed. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Examination reveals a moderate left knee effusion, slight warmth without erythema, and no ligamentous laxity or joint locking. Laboratory results show elevated ESR (46 mm/hr), normal blood counts, and creatinine. X-ray reveals linear calcifications of the menisci and articular cartilage, and synovial fluid analysis shows 15,400/mm³ leukocytes (80% neutrophils) with a negative Gram stain. Which of the following additional tests is most appropriate in the evaluation of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum iron studies

 

  • This patient presents with acute monoarthritis with X-ray evidence of chondrocalcinosis (cartilage calcification), suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD or pseudogout). 
  • Given his young age (33 years old), an underlying metabolic disorder should be considered, with hemochromatosis being the most common metabolic cause of CPPD. 
  • Serum iron studies (iron, ferritin, transferrin saturation) are the best next step to evaluate for hereditary hemochromatosis, which can present with early-onset arthritis, diabetes, liver dysfunction, and skin pigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody assay: Used for diagnosing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which presents as symmetrical polyarthritis (MCP, PIP, wrists) rather than acute monoarthritis.

 

Option B. Antinuclear antibody and double-stranded DNA antibody assay: Used for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which typically presents with polyarthritis, rash, and systemic symptoms, not isolated acute knee arthritis with chondrocalcinosis.

 

Option C. HLA-B27 testing: Associated with spondyloarthropathies (ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, IBD-associated arthritis), which cause axial symptoms (back pain), enthesitis, or dactylitis, not acute monoarthritis with chondrocalcinosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD or pseudogout) in a young patient should raise suspicion for metabolic conditions such as hemochromatosis. Serum iron studies are the best next step in evaluation.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Components of Cell Membrane and Their Functions

 

Column A (Components of cell Membrane)

 

  1. Phosphatidylcholine
  2. Cardiolipin
  3. Cholesterol
  4. Glycolipids

 

Column B (Functions)

 

  1.  Prevents RBC hemolysis and is abundant in the CNS
  2. Exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and linked to Syphilis
  3. Maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer
  4. Major component of surfactant
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

1-D: Phosphatidylcholine is the major component of surfactant, essential for reducing surface tension in alveoli.
 

2-B: Cardiolipin is exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and is implicated in Syphilis (anticardiolipin antibodies).
 

3-C: Cholesterol maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer, modulating the rigidity of the lipid bilayer.
 

4-A: Glycolipids, including cerebrosides and gangliosides, are abundant in the CNS and GIT, respectively, and help in preventing hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Phosphatidylcholine is the major component of surfactant, essential for reducing surface tension in alveoli.
  • Cardiolipin is exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and is implicated in Syphilis (anticardiolipin antibodies).
  • Cholesterol maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer, modulating the rigidity of the lipid bilayer.
  • Glycolipids, including cerebrosides and gangliosides, are abundant in the CNS and GIT, respectively, and help in preventing hemolysis.

questions.text:
Which of the following combinations is incorrect regarding the characteristics of the stretch reflex?

 

  1. The receptor for the stretch reflex is the muscle spindle.
  2. The afferent nerve fibers involved are Group Ib fibers.
  3. The efferent nerve fibers in the stretch reflex are α-motor neurons.
  4. The stretch reflex is disynaptic
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 4

 

  • Statement 2: The afferent nerve fibers involved are Group Ib fibers: The afferent nerve fibers involved in the stretch reflex are Group Ia and II endings, not Group Ib fibers (these are associated with the inverse stretch reflex).
  • Statement 4: The stretch reflex is disynaptic: The stretch reflex is indeed disynaptic

 

Other Options:

 

  • Statement 1: The receptor for the stretch reflex is the muscle spindle: This is correct as the receptor for the stretch reflex is indeed the muscle spindle.
  • Statement 3: The efferent nerve fibers in the stretch reflex are α-motor neurons: This is correct since the efferent nerve fibers involved are α-motor neurons, which stimulate the contraction of the muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormality is most commonly associated with condition as shown in the CT image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)Trisomy 13

 

  • Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder where the prosencephalon (forebrain) fails to divide into two hemispheres.
  • This results in alobar holoprosencephaly, characterized by a single ventricular cavity and fusion of brain structures, leading to the "pancake" brain appearance on CT scans.
  • The condition is most commonly associated with Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), a genetic disorder that involves severe malformation of the brain, heart, and other organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome): Incorrect. Trisomy 21 is associated with structural brain abnormalities such as ventricular dilation, but it does not cause holoprosencephaly.

 

Option B. Trisomy 18 (Edwards Syndrome): Incorrect. Trisomy 18 is associated with congenital anomalies like rocker-bottom feet and micrognathia, but holoprosencephaly is rare.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome (45, XO):Incorrect. Turner syndrome presents with features like webbed neck, coarctation of the aorta, and short stature, but does not cause holoprosencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is commonly associated with alobar holoprosencephaly, characterized by fusion of the frontal lobes and pancake brain sign on imaging.

questions.text: From where does the fiber bundle marked with an arrow (A) in the following cut section of brain originate?
questions.solution:
Ans B) Amygdala

 

  • The fiber bundle marked in the image represents the stria terminalis, which originates from the amygdala.  
  • The stria terminalis is a major output pathway of the amygdala that connects it to the hypothalamus, particularly the anterior hypothalamus and septal nuclei. 
  • It plays a role in emotional and autonomic regulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hippocampus: The hippocampus primarily gives rise to the fornix, which connects it to the mammillary bodies and the septal nuclei. The stria terminalis is not associated with the hippocampus.

 

Option C. Mammillary bodies: These structures are primarily connected to the hippocampus via the fornix and do not give rise to the stria terminalis.

 

Option D. Insular cortex: The insular cortex is involved in functions such as taste perception and emotional responses but does not contribute fibers to the stria terminalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stria terminalis is a major output pathway of the amygdala, connecting it to the hypothalamus and septal nuclei. 
  • It plays a key role in the regulation of emotions and autonomic responses.

questions.text: Which nerve is most likely affected, based on the hand posture shown in the image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • Claw Hand deformity is a condition where the fingers are bent into a position that looks like a claw. 
  • It may affect all of the fingers or only some of them depending on its cause. 
  • Claw Hand is a hand deformity with hyperextension of the MCP joints and flexion of the IP joints due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. 
  • Claw Hand deformity can be complete when it involves all the digits due to both ulnar and median nerve palsy, or it can be incomplete/partial where it involves only ulnar 2 digits due to isolated ulnar nerve palsy.
  • Signs and Symptoms:
    • Muscle wasting of the interrosseous and hypothenar
    • Numbness along the nerve involved
    • Inability to extend the IP joints during extension of the fingers, to abduct and adduct fingers
    • Unopposed action of the extensors and the flexors digitorum profundus as the lumbricals of digits 4 and 5 are paralyzed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve: Compression, stretch, or traumatic disruption of the nerve may result in median nerve palsies. Most commonly, palsies of the median nerve are caused by compression at the carpal tunnel, known as carpal tunnel syndrome. Women have 3 times higher incidence of carpal tunnel syndrome compared to men. It peaks around age 50 but also frequently present in the older population. Patients with diabetes and thyroid disease are at an increased risk for carpal tunnel syndrome. With carpal tunnel syndrome, weakness in the thenar eminence is observed. Isolation of the opponens pollicis power is done by asking the patient to palmarly abduct the thumb. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: Isolated injuries of the Musculocutaneous Nerve are rare. It may become injured by brachial Plexus damage, compression injury, dislocation of the shoulder, shoulder surgery, or entrapment of the nerve at the elbow. Most significant is the entrapment of the musculocutaneous nerve within the coracobrachialis muscle, leading to biceps brachii and brachialis weakness and atrophy with accompanying loss of sensation in the lateral forearm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows Claw hand deformity wherein the MCP joint of the fingers is hyperextended while the IP joint is flexed in the 4th and 5th digits. 
  • This occurs due to weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hand which are supplied by the ulnar nerve. 
  • Thus, ulnar nerve palsies lead to claw hand deformity.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about placenta accreta is true?

 

  1. The incidence is about 1 in 2500 pregnancies
  2. The incidence has increased in the last decade
  3. It is caused by the absence of decidua basalis
  4. The fibrinoid layer is deficient
  5. It is more common in primigravida
questions.solution:
Ans. B) b, c, d

 

b. The incidence has increased in the last decade: The incidence of placenta accreta has increased significantly over the last decade, largely due to the rise in cesarean sections, which predispose women to abnormal placental adherence in subsequent pregnancies.

 

c. It is caused by the absence of decidua basalis: Placenta accreta occurs when the decidua basalis is absent, allowing the placental villi to attach directly to the myometrium.

 

d. The fibrinoid layer is deficient: The absence or poor development of Nitabuch’s fibrinoid layer further contributes to abnormal adherence of the placenta to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

a. The incidence is about 1 in 2500 pregnancies: This is false. While earlier estimates suggested an incidence of 1 in 2500, recent data show the incidence is closer to 1 in 550 deliveries due to the increasing rates of cesarean sections.

 

e. It is more common in primigravida: This is false. Placenta accreta is more common in women with multiple pregnancies, especially those with a history of placenta previa or prior cesarean deliveries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta accreta is associated with the absence of the decidua basalis and a deficient fibrinoid layer, and its incidence has increased with rising cesarean delivery rates. 
  • It is more common in women with a history of cesarean sections and placenta previa, not in primigravida.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with headaches, vision changes, and hormonal imbalances. Imaging finding is shown below. The lesion is likely originating from which of the following embryonic structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rathke's pouch

 

  • The lesion described is most likely a craniopharyngioma, which arises from Rathke’s pouch. 
  • It is a cystic lesion commonly located in the suprasellar region with calcification, and it extends near the pituitary stalk. 
  • Rathke's pouch is an embryological remnant that gives rise to the anterior pituitary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neural tube: The neural tube gives rise to the central nervous system structures, not craniopharyngiomas.

 

Option C. Adenohypophysis: This is the anterior part of the pituitary gland, but craniopharyngiomas are not derived from this structure.

 

Option D. Mesodermal layer: This layer does not give rise to the structures seen in craniopharyngiomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Craniopharyngiomas arise from Rathke’s pouch and are characterized by cystic formation and calcifications on imaging.

choices.text: Continue OHA and reduce long-acting insulin dose by half.
Discontinue OHA and administer short-acting insulin as needed.
Continue OHA and administer long-acting insulin at full dose.
Discontinue OHA, reduce long-acting insulin to one-third, and monitor glucose closely.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male on oral hypoglycemic agents (OHA) and long-acting insulin is scheduled for an elective hernia repair. His preoperative glucose level is 140 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate perioperative glucose management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Discontinue OHA, reduce long-acting insulin to one-third, and monitor glucose closely.

 

  • Long-acting insulin is reduced to one-third to prevent intraoperative hypoglycemia, and OHA is stopped to avoid unpredictable glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue OHA and reduce long-acting insulin dose by half: Reducing insulin by half may still lead to hypoglycemia during fasting.

 

Option B. Discontinue OHA and administer short-acting insulin as needed: Short-acting insulin may be needed postoperatively but is not routinely administered preoperatively.

 

Option C. Continue OHA and administer long-acting insulin at full dose: Continuing full-dose insulin risks severe hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In diabetic patients undergoing surgery, careful preoperative insulin adjustment and glucose monitoring are crucial to prevent hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a 6-month history of progressive pain and swelling in both knees. The pain is particularly aggravated by activity, and he has noticed a decrease in range of motion in the joint. On physical examination, there is moderate effusion and tenderness over the joint line. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synovial Chondromatosis

 

  • Synovial chondromatosis is a rare benign condition where the synovial membrane of joints forms multiple cartilaginous nodules. 
  • These nodules can become free-floating bodies within the joint, and over time, they may undergo calcification or ossification.
  • It results from the metaplasia of the synovial lining, leading to the formation of cartilaginous nodules, which may later calcify or ossify. 
  • These free-floating nodules can cause pain, joint effusion, and limited range of motion, as the synovium becomes inflamed and irritated.
  • X-rays typically reveal multiple, well-defined, round or oval-shaped calcified bodies within the joint, which may be free-floating or fixed to the synovial lining. 
  • The classic "popcorn" appearance on imaging is a hallmark of synovial chondromatosis.
  • Pain, swelling, stiffness, and a decreased range of motion are common due to irritation of the synovium, along with mechanical symptoms from free-floating bodies in the joint.
  • Most commonly affects large joints like the knee, hip, or elbow, and it can involve both unilateral and bilateral joints. 
  • The knee is a very common site of involvement.
  • Surgical excision of the nodules is the treatment of choice, and the prognosis is generally good once the nodules are removed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Synovial Sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma is a malignant soft tissue tumour that often arises near large joints, usually in the deep tissues of the limbs. It can occur in younger adults, commonly affecting the knee or elbow. It is a malignant tumour that arises from synovial tissue or surrounding soft tissues. Synovial sarcoma is typically characterized by a complex chromosomal translocation (t(X;18)), which leads to abnormal gene expression. Synovial sarcoma may present as a soft tissue mass near the joint. X-ray may show a well-circumscribed mass or calcifications within the soft tissue, but the tumour itself is often better seen on MRI or CT. These masses can be heterogeneous and irregular in shape, often extending into the joint or surrounding structures. Symptoms are usually related to the mass effect of the tumour. Patients may present with a palpable mass, pain, swelling, and decreased joint mobility due to the tumour’s involvement of the soft tissues around the joint. Pain often worsens with activity. Synovial sarcoma can be diagnosed with imaging studies (MRI is most helpful) and confirmed with biopsy to detect characteristic histological features. Treatment usually involves surgical resection, and adjuvant chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy may be necessary depending on the stage.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumour that often arises in the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee. It is more common in adolescents and young adults. Osteosarcoma arises from the osteoblasts and typically produces bone or osteoid. It can be associated with a genetic mutation (e.g., in the TP53 gene), and it often occurs in the metaphysis of long bones (femur, tibia, humerus). X-rays often show a destructive bone lesion with an aggressive appearance. There is typically an ill-defined periosteal reaction, which may result in the formation of a "Codman's triangle" (a raised periosteum seen on the edge of a tumour). There may also be bone fragmentation or a mixed lytic and sclerotic pattern in the lesion. Osteosarcoma typically presents with localized pain, swelling, and, in some cases, a palpable mass. The pain often worsens over time, and there may be a history of injury that exacerbates the pain. It often presents in the younger population, typically between ages 10 and 30. Imaging studies (X-ray, MRI) and biopsy are used for diagnosis. CT scans or PET scans may be performed to evaluate for metastasis, as osteosarcoma commonly metastasizes to the lungs. Treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy and surgical resection of the tumour.

 

 

Option D. Giant Cell Tumour: Giant cell tumour (GCT) is a benign but locally aggressive bone tumour that commonly affects the epiphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee. Giant cell tumours are composed of multinucleated giant cells and are typically found in the epiphyseal region of long bones. Although they are benign, they can cause significant local bone destruction and may recur after surgery. X-rays often show a lytic, expansile lesion in the epiphysis of long bones, commonly affecting the distal femur, proximal tibia, or radius. The lesion has a "soap bubble" appearance, with well-defined borders but an expansile, destructive nature. Giant cell tumours typically present with pain, swelling, and a decrease in range of motion, especially in weight-bearing joints. However, it is usually a solitary lesion and not typically associated with multiple nodules or calcifications in the joint space. Imaging studies and biopsy are used to confirm the diagnosis. MRI is helpful to determine the extent of the tumour, and biopsy confirms the presence of multinucleated giant cells. Treatment involves curettage and bone grafting, although recurrence is common. In some cases, surgical resection or joint replacement may be required.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While giant cell tumours can cause pain and swelling in the knee, they typically do not present with multiple calcified bodies in the joint space. 
  • The radiographic appearance would be more characteristic of a lytic lesion rather than the calcified nodules of synovial chondromatosis.

choices.text: MRI of the brain and orbits

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive vision loss in his left eye. B-scan ultrasonography image is shown below. What is the next best diagnostic step in confirming the nature of this lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA)

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is the next best diagnostic step in patients with suspected choroidal melanoma. 
  • FFA helps evaluate the vascularity of the lesion, which is critical for distinguishing malignant melanomas from benign lesions. 
  • Choroidal melanomas typically exhibit early hyperfluorescence with late leakage on FFA, reflecting the tumor's vascular characteristics. 
  • This information is essential for accurate diagnosis and planning treatment.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Optical coherence tomography (OCT): Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is useful for assessing retinal thickness and macular conditions but does not provide the necessary information to evaluate a choroidal melanoma's vascularity.
 

Option C. Complete blood count (CBC): A complete blood count (CBC) is not useful for diagnosing choroidal melanoma and would not provide relevant information for this patient.
 

Option D. MRI of the brain and orbits: MRI of the brain and orbits can be helpful in assessing the extent of intraocular and orbital involvement but is not the primary tool for diagnosing choroidal melanoma. FFA is more specific for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) is essential for assessing the vascular characteristics of suspected choroidal melanoma and is crucial for confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A boy fell while playing and suffered an abrasion injury on his knees. The dark brown scab will be seen in how many days? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-7 days

 

Explanation:

 

Abrasions heal in a predictable manner, forming a scab due to drying of blood, serum, and tissue fluids. The color of the scab changes over time, providing a reliable estimate of injury duration:

 

Timeline of Scab Formation in Abrasions

 

  1. Day 1 (Fresh wound) → Bright red due to oozing blood & lymph.
  2. 12-24 hours → Reddish scab begins to form.
  3. 2-3 days → Reddish-brown scab develops.
  4. 4-7 days → Dark brown to black scab appears as the wound dries​
  5. >7 days → Scab begins to peel off, leaving a depigmented area that gradually fades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Day 1:  Incorrect. Fresh abrasion will appear bright red with oozing blood and lymph, not a dark brown scab.

 

Option B. 2-3 days:  Incorrect. Scab forms but is reddish-brown, not dark brown.

 

Option D. >7 days:  Incorrect. By >7 days, the scab starts falling off, revealing new epithelium underneath.

 

Educational Objective:


Age of Abrasion

questions.text: A cephalic index of 82 belongs to which racial group? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mongoloid

 

Explanation:

 

Cephalic Index (CI) Formula:

 

Cephalic index =  (Maximum breadth of skull/Maximum length of skull) × 100 


Classification based on cephalic index:

 

  • Dolichocephalic (70-75): Found in Aryans, Negroes, Aborigines (ANA)
  • Mesaticephalic (75-80): Found in Europeans (Caucasians), Indians, Chinese
  • Brachycephalic (80-85): Found in Mongoloids 

 

A cephalic index of 82 falls in the brachycephalic range, which is characteristic of Mongoloid populations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negroid: Incorrect. Negroid skulls are Dolichocephalic (CI 70- 75), meaning they have a long, narrow skull

​

Option C. Caucasian: Incorrect. Caucasian skulls are Mesaticephalic (CI: 75-80), meaning they have a medium-sized skull

​

Option D. Chinese: Incorrect. Chinese skulls are Mesaticephalic (CI: 75-80), meaning they have a medium-sized skull

​

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought to the hospital with burn injuries on the right side of the body, including the upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg, mostly on the front. What is the estimated burn percentage? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate the burn percentage in infants, the Lund & Browder chart is used.

 

  • In children surface area of Head is more, and  Lower limbs less as compared to adults:
    • Head is “18% - Age”; 
    • Each lower limb is “14% + (0.5 X Age)”
  • Above rule applicable till about 9 years of age (because after that almost similar to adults, so rule of 9 can be used)
  • Other Body Parts (Trunks, Upper limbs): same proportion of body in child as that of Adults
  • So in a 1 year child:
    • Head: 18%- 1= 17% (Front 8.5% + Back 8.5%)
    • Each Lower limb: 14% + 0.5 (1)= 14.5% (Front 7.25% + Back 7.25%) 
    • Chest: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Abdomen: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Each Upper limb: 9% (Front 4.5% + Back 4.5%): Same As Adults

    • Perinium: 1%: Same As Adults

       

Calculating Burn Area for the Right Side (Front Only) for a 1 year child

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-10% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is too low.

 

Option C. 25-35% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is high.

 

Option D. >50% : Incorrect. This would require extensive burns covering most of the body, which is not observed in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants, the burn percentage is calculated differently than in adults, using the Lund & Browder chart. In this case, burns affecting the only right side of body and only on front on upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg contribute to 15-25% total body surface area (TBSA)​

questions.text: After a myocardial infarction (MI), staining was done using Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) Most myocardial tissue got stained in brick red color, while some tissue remained pale. What is the minimum survival time required post MI for this color change to appear? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2-3 hours

 

Explanation:

 

The Triphenyl Tetrazolium Chloride (TTC) test is used to detect early myocardial infarction (MI) by staining viable cardiac tissue.

 

  • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 12 hours for any  gross changes in the heart to be visible.
  • The minimum survival time required Post MI is generally around 6 hours for any  microscopic changes in the heart to be visible.

 

However, with the use of TTC staining, gross changes in the heart can be observed as early as 2-3 hours post-MI.

 

  • In normal tissue, mitochondrial enzymes such as dehydrogenases are present, which reduce TTC, resulting in a brick-red color.
  • In infarcted tissue, the infarcted area remains pale due to the absence of these mitochondrial enzymes, which are affected by the lack of blood supply.
  • Complete mitochondrial enzyme death typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time, post-MI.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. 1 hour: Incorrect. The TTC reaction typically requires at least 2-3 hours of survival time after MI for a clear distinction between infarcted and normal tissue to be visible.

 

Option C. 6-12 hours: Incorrect. While TTC can detect MI after 2-3 hours, the question specifically asks about the minimum time, not a broader window.

 

Option D. > 24 hours: Incorrect. The TTC test can detect MI much earlier than 24 hours. The question is asking about the minimum time needed for the color change to appear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TTC test is used to detect early MI. A brick-red color appears in viable myocardium, while the infarcted area remains pale after 2-3 hours post-MI. 

 

Note that some sources suggest a minimum survival time of 4 hours for TTC positivity instead of 2-3 hours.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to follow-up after being treated for typhoid fever. His Laboratory findings reveal a Widal test with O antigen titer >1:20, H antigen titer >1:320, HA titer >1:20, and BH titer >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery

 

In the Widal test, the O antigen titer is expected to be >1:100 in acute infection, while the H antigen titer >1:200 suggests a recent or past infection. Here, the O antigen is low (1:20) while H antigen is high (1:320), indicating that the patient is in the recovery phase rather than acute infection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute infection: Would show high O antigen titers as O antigen rises early in infection

 

Option B. Chronic infection: Both O and H titers would be low/flat

 

Option C. Past infection: Both O and H titers would be low/flat

 

Educational Objective:

 

In enteric fever recovery phase, O antigen titers fall while H antigen titers remain elevated before gradually declining.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is dependent on Vitamin C for its activity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prolyl hydroxylase

 

Prolyl hydroxylase is a key enzyme in collagen synthesis that requires vitamin C (ascorbic acid) as a cofactor. This enzyme catalyzes the hydroxylation of proline residues to form hydroxyproline in collagen. The process is essential for:

 

  • Post-translational modification of collagen
  • Formation of stable collagen triple helix
  • Proper collagen cross-linking
  • Maintaining collagen strength and stability

 

In vitamin C deficiency, proline cannot be hydroxylated to hydroxyproline, leading to unstable collagen and symptoms of scurvy like:

 

  • Poor wound healing
  • Bleeding gums
  • Easy bruising

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect because this enzyme does not exist in collagen synthesis pathway. The actual enzyme involved in lysine modification is lysyl hydroxylase, which also requires vitamin C.

 

Option B. Lysyl oxidase: Incorrect because this enzyme requires copper as a cofactor, not vitamin C. It forms cross-links in collagen by oxidizing lysine and hydroxylysine residues.

 

Option C. Hydroxypropyl kinase: Incorrect because this is a non-existent enzyme name. No such enzyme is involved in collagen synthesis or vitamin C-dependent reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for prolyl hydroxylase, which is crucial for collagen synthesis and stability. Deficiency of vitamin C leads to defective collagen formation resulting in scurvy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with a history of 2 months of amenorrhea. A urine pregnancy test is positive. On speculum examination, the following finding is observed. Identify the sign seen? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chadwick’s sign

 

The image shows a speculum examination of the cervix demonstrating a bluish/purplish discoloration, which is known as Chadwick's sign or Jacquemier's sign. This is one of the earliest visible signs of pregnancy, caused by increased vascularity and venous congestion of the cervix and vagina during early pregnancy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Osiander sign: This is incorrect. Osiander sign refers to the pulsations felt in the lateral fornix due to increased vascularity of uterine arteries in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Hegar sign: This is incorrect. Hegar sign is elicited during bimanual examination where there is softening of the lower uterine segment, allowing the examiner's fingers to almost meet between the cervix and uterine body.

 

Option D. Placental sign: This is incorrect. Placental sign refers to implantation bleeding that occurs when the embryo implants in the uterus.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chadwick's sign (bluish discoloration of cervix and vagina) as one of the early visible signs of pregnancy during speculum examination, distinguishing it from other early pregnancy signs like Hegar's and Osiander's signs.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with delayed periods and vaginal bleeding. An ultrasound reveals retained products of conception, and a suction evacuation is performed. The extracted tissue is sent for histopathology, which reports a karyotype of 46XX and is p57kip2 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complete mole

 

The diagnosis is complete mole based on two key findings:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX) - Complete moles typically have a diploid karyotype
  2. p57kip2 negative staining - p57kip2 is a paternally imprinted, maternally expressed gene. Its negative expression is diagnostic of complete mole as there is no maternal genetic material

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Partial mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • Partial moles have triploid karyotype (69XXX or 69XXY)
  • p57kip2 is positive in partial moles due to presence of maternal genetic material

 

Option C. Invasive mole - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a complication of molar pregnancy where the mole invades the myometrium
  • Diagnosis requires imaging evidence of myometrial invasion
  • Karyotype alone cannot diagnose invasive mole

 

Option D. Choriocarcinoma - Incorrect because:

 

  • This is a malignant form of gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Diagnosis is based on histopathology showing malignant trophoblastic tissue
  • Cannot be diagnosed by karyotype and p57kip2 staining alone

 

Educational Objective: 

 

complete molar pregnancy is characterized by:

 

  1. Diploid karyotype (46XX)
  2. Negative p57kip2 staining
  3. Complete absence of maternal genetic material

questions.text: Identify the type of epiphysis marked in the given image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure epiphysis

 

Pressure epiphysis is the part of the bone that bear weight or pressure during movement and are located at the ends of long bones. In the image, the tibia and fibula clearly show the ends where pressure is applied during articulation and weight-bearing, marking these regions as pressure epiphyses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Traction epiphysis: Incorrect. Traction epiphyses are involved with ligament or tendon attachment points, such as the trochanters of the femur (like greater and lesser trochanters). These do not bear direct weight.

 

Option C. Aberrant epiphysis: Incorrect. Aberrant epiphyses are usually abnormal and occur in locations where epiphyses are not typically present, like the head of the first metacarpal​. They are not typically found at major weight-bearing joints.
