Option D. Atavistic epiphysis: Incorrect. Atavistic epiphyses are evolutionary remnants that were previously separate bones in ancestral species but are fused now, such as the coracoid process of the scapula​. They are not related to weight-bearing functions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient is undergoing breast surgery, during which several structures are retracted, as shown in the image. Identify the marked muscle given in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serratus anterior

 

The serratus anterior muscle is clearly visible and marked in the provided image

 

  • The serratus anterior muscle is located on the lateral aspect of the thoracic wall and plays a critical role in scapular protraction and stabilization.
  • It originates from the first to eighth ribs and inserts on the medial border of the scapula.
  • This muscle is often encountered during breast surgeries, mastectomies, and axillary lymph node dissections, where it may need to be retracted to access deeper structures.
  • Is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (nerve of Bell) 
  • Acts as the "boxer's muscle" as it has punching and pushing ability 
  • Its paralysis leads to winging of scapula

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subscapularis: Incorrect. The subscapularis muscle is part of the rotator cuff muscles and lies deep to the scapula. It is not visible in this view as it is located in Bicipital Groove. Also called as “Forgotten muscle of the Rotator Cuff”

 

Option B. Teres major: Incorrect. It lies posterior wall of axilla, It is not visible in the surgical field during breast surgery

 

Option C. Latissimus dorsi: Incorrect. While the latissimus dorsi muscle is in proximity to the posterior thoracic wall and can be involved in breast reconstruction surgeries (e.g., flap procedures), it does not align with the location or appearance of the marked muscle in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The serratus anterior is a critical muscle encountered in breast surgeries due to its position along the lateral thoracic wall and proximity to the axilla.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

The histological image shows the thymus, a primary lymphoid organ responsible for T-cell maturation. Key features of the thymus seen in the image include:

 

  • Lobular architecture with a cortex (darker staining due to densely packed immature T cells) and a medulla (lighter staining due to less dense mature T cells).
  • Presence of Hassall's corpuscles in the medulla, which are unique to the thymus.
  • Absence of lymphoid follicles, which differentiates it from secondary lymphoid organs like lymph nodes and spleen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Incorrect. A lymph node has distinct cortical follicles, germinal centers, and a medullary sinus. The image does not show any of these structures, ruling out the lymph node.

 

Option B. Palatine Tonsil: Incorrect. Palatine tonsils contain lymphoid follicles and crypts. Crypts are absent in the given image, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Spleen: Incorrect. The spleen exhibits red pulp (vascular sinusoidal spaces) and white pulp (lymphoid nodules with central arterioles). These features are absent in the image, excluding the spleen as the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer treated with radiation therapy presents to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath and a non-productive cough for the past 3 weeks. A chest X-ray reveals a hazy opacification over the left lung field. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiation pneumonitis

 

Explanation:

 

Radiation pneumonitis is the most likely diagnosis. This condition typically develops 3-12 weeks after radiation therapy. The features supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  • History of radiation therapy for breast cancer
  • Progressive shortness of breath and non-productive cough
  • Chest X-ray showing hazy opacification in the left lung field (corresponding to the radiation field near the breast)
  • Timing of symptoms (3 weeks post-radiation): If left untreated, radiation pneumonitis can progress to radiation-induced fibrosis after several years.

 

Early (Acute) Radiation Pneumonitis:

 

  • Occurs 3-12 weeks post-radiation therapy
  • Caused by direct radiation damage to lung tissue leading to inflammation
  • Symptoms include: 
    • Progressive dyspnea
    • Non-productive cough
    • Sometimes low-grade fever
  • Radiological findings: 
    • Hazy opacification confined to the radiation port
    • Often shows a straight edge corresponding to radiation field
    • May show ground-glass appearance

 

Late (Chronic) Radiation Pneumonitis:

 

  • Develops 6-12 months after radiation
  • Can progress to radiation fibrosis
  • Shows permanent scarring and volume loss in affected area

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism:

 

  • More acute onset of sudden dyspnea, often with pleuritic chest pain and possibly hemoptysis.
  • Usually diagnosed via CT pulmonary angiography rather than chest X-ray.

 

Option B. Infective pneumonia:

 

  • Presents with productive cough, fever, leukocytosis.
  • Chest X-ray may show lobar consolidation, rather than hazy opacification.

 

Option D. Lung metastasis:

 

  • Typically presents as multiple nodular lesions on chest imaging.
  • Less likely to cause progressive dyspnea and non-productive cough alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiation pneumonitis is a delayed inflammatory reaction to radiation therapy, presenting with progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and localized hazy opacification on imaging. Diagnosis is clinical and radiologic, and treatment involves corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia that is more pronounced for liquids than solids. He reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food and has significant weight loss over the past few months. A barium swallow study is performed. Which radiological sign is most likely to be observed? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rat-tail sign

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation strongly suggests achalasia cardia, a primary motility disorder of the esophagus. 

 

  • Dysphagia more pronounced for liquids than solids (characteristic of achalasia)
  • The pattern is explained by the pathophysiology: liquids lack the mass and gravity effect to push through the non-relaxing lower esophageal sphincter, while solids can generate more pressure to pass through
  • Regurgitation of undigested food
  • Weight loss due to feeding difficulties 
  • The bird beak sign, showing a smooth, symmetrical tapering of the distal esophagus, is the classic radiological finding in achalasia on barium swallow. 
  • The rat tail sign, often used for carcinoma esophagus has also been described for achalasia. 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corkscrew esophagus: This appearance is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm, a different motility disorder with intermittent dysphagia.

 

Option B. Apple-core lesion: This is typically seen in colonic carcinoma, appearing as a symmetric narrowing with overhanging edges. It's not associated with esophageal disorders.

 

Option C. String sign: This is typically seen in CHPS in the pylorus and TB and Chron’s disease in the ileum and represents narrowing. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In achalasia, dysphagia is characteristically worse for liquids than solids due to the underlying motility disorder affecting lower esophageal sphincter relaxation, with bird beak sign and rat tail sign being the characteristic radiological finding on barium swallow.

questions.text: The imaging shows a detailed cross-sectional view of the esophageal wall and surrounding structures. What is the primary use of this imaging modality? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staging of esophageal cancer

 

Explanation:

 

  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is primarily used for staging esophageal cancer, particularly for T (tumor) and N (nodal) staging. Its high-resolution imaging capabilities allow detailed visualization of the esophageal wall layers and surrounding lymph nodes. However, for M (metastasis) staging, PET-CT remains the investigation of choice, as is true for most cancers.

 

Additional uses of EUS include:

 

  • Assessment of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, particularly gastrinomas in the duodenum
  • Evaluation of biliary microlithiasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identifying the cause of dysphagia: While EUS can visualize esophageal structures, it's not the primary tool for diagnosing causes of dysphagia. Standard endoscopy and barium studies are more commonly used for this purpose.

 

Option C. Assessing cardiac and aortic pathology: This is done using transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), which is a different procedure where the ultrasound probe faces anteriorly to examine the heart, rather than examining the esophageal wall itself.

 

Option D. Evaluation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): 24-hour pH monitoring is the standard test for GERD evaluation. EUS is not routinely used for this purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endoscopic ultrasound is the investigation of choice for T and N staging of esophageal cancer, while PET-CT is used for M staging.

questions.text: Identify the X-ray shown below: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary edema

 

Explanation:

 

Pulmonary edema is characterized by the bat-wing appearance on chest X-ray, which consists of bilateral perihilar opacities with a central distribution. This pattern is due to fluid accumulation in the lung interstitium and alveoli, commonly seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

 

Typical X-ray findings of pulmonary edema include:

 

  • Bilateral perihilar opacities (bat-wing distribution)
  • Kerley B lines (horizontal lines indicating interstitial edema)
  • Cardiomegaly (if due to heart failure)
  • Pleural effusions in severe cases

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleural Effusion: Characterized by blunting of the costophrenic angles and a meniscus sign due to fluid accumulation in the pleural space.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Fibrosis: Shows reticular opacities in the lower lung zones, often with honeycombing and volume loss. It does not have a central perihilar distribution.

 

Option D. Hydrothorax: Similar to pleural effusion, hydrothorax refers to fluid accumulation in the pleural space, seen as homogeneous opacity with a fluid level

​

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary edema presents with a bat-wing appearance on chest X-ray, characterized by bilateral perihilar opacities, Kerley B lines, and signs of interstitial fluid accumulation.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of multiple episodes of seizures and hypoglycemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates hepatocytes with large glycogen stores. Biochemical analysis reveals glycogen with short outer chains. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
What is the most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)

 

 

  • Mapleson Circuit Type A[Magill’s] is most effective for Spontaneous Ventilation.
  • For spontaneous breathing, the efficiency of Mapleson circuits (from most to least effective) is: A > D > C > B
  • Efficiency Order for Controlled Ventilation (from best → worst) :D > B > C > A

 

Explanation of Circuits - (Mapleson Classification):

 

  • Type A (Magill’s circuit / Mapleson A):
    • Most efficient for spontaneous breathing (least fresh gas flow required).
    • Requires only ~70 mL/kg/min fresh gas flow.
    • Commonly used in adults.
    • Lac’s circuit is Co-axial modification of Magill’s Circuit.
  • Type B & C:
    • Rarely used.
    • Less efficient both for controlled and spontaneous ventilation.
  • Type D (Bain’s circuit – coaxial modification):
    • Most efficient for controlled ventilation, but not ideal for spontaneous breathing.
  • Type E (Ayre’s T-piece):
    • Used in pediatrics, no valves, minimal dead space.
    • Inefficient in adults due to high fresh gas requirement.
  • Type F (Jackson-Rees modification of T-piece):
    • Mostly pediatric use; allows scavenging of gases.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed the following capnograph. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition?

A 65-year-old man who had multiple episodes of pain abdomen and passage of foul-smelling greasy stools for the past 5 months shows the following CT findings. The TIGAR-O system used in the assessment of the underlying condition is related to which of the following?
Which of the following pairs of drugs act on the same receptor but have opposite effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diazoxide and nateglinide

 

Diazoxide opens pancreatic K⁺ ATP channels (↓ insulin release), whereas nateglinide closes them (↑ insulin release). Both act on the same receptor (K⁺ ATP channel) but produce opposite effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin & octreotide: Both inhibit hormone secretion, similar effect.

 

Option B. Thioridazine & haloperidol: Both dopamine antagonists, same effect.

 

Option C. Pioglitazone & gemfibrozil: Act on different receptors (PPAR-γ vs PPAR-α).

questions.text: Particle diameter size most commonly responsible for causation of Pneumoconioses in industries is? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.5-3 micron

 

The particle size of dust plays a crucial role in causing pneumoconiosis. Particles of size 0.5-3 micron are most dangerous because:

 

  • They are small enough to be inhaled deep into the lungs
  • Can reach up to alveoli
  • Stick to alveolar walls
  • Cause pneumoconiosis by damaging lung tissue

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. <5 micron: This option is too broad and includes particles below 0.5 micron which are in Brownian motion and don't cause damage as they move in and out with respiration 

 

Option C. 5-10 micron: These particles are too large to reach deep lung tissue and get trapped in the upper respiratory tract 

 

Option D. >10 micron: These particles are so large that they fall on the machine where they are generated and don't enter respiratory system

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dust particles of size 0.5-3 micron are most dangerous for causing pneumoconiosis as they can reach and damage alveoli.

 

PNEUMOCONIOSES

 

  • D/t occupational exposure to dust
  • < 0.5 µ → Always in Brownian motion [Moves in & out]
  • 0.5 - 3µ → Most dangerous particle size
    • 3- 5µ → Trapped by mid respiratory tract
    • 5- 10µ → Trapped by upper resp. tract
    • 10µ → Fall on machine

- Common Pneumoconiosis

questions.text: Identify A and B in the image given: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-Anopheles, B-Culex

 

The image shows mosquito larvae in water. Anopheles larvae (A) rest parallel to the water surface because they have no siphon tube and can take oxygen directly through the water surface and skin. In contrast, Culex larvae (B) have a siphon tube (like a nose) so they attach to water surface at an angle using this siphon tube. The characteristic positioning of these larvae helps in their identification - Anopheles parallel to surface, while Culex at an angle.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. A-Culex, B-Aedes: Incorrect because Culex larvae rest at an angle to water surface, not parallel like shown in A.

 

Option C. A-Culex, B-Anopheles: Incorrect because the positioning is reversed. Anopheles rests parallel (A), not B.

 

Option D. A-Aedes, B-Culex: Incorrect because Aedes larvae, like Culex, have a siphon tube and rest at an angle, not parallel like shown in A.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks, 16-24 months, 5 years
At birth, 6 weeks, 10 weeks, 14 weeks

questions.text: What is the f-IPV dose schedule under the National Immunization Schedule of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6 weeks, 14 weeks, 9 months

 

Under the National Immunization Schedule of India, fractional IPV (f-IPV) is given in three doses:

 

  • First dose at 6 weeks
  • Second dose at 14 weeks (no dose at 10 weeks)
  • Third dose at 9 months

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fractional IPV (f-IPV) schedule in India's National Immunization Schedule consists of three doses at 6 weeks, 14 weeks, and 9 months.

questions.text: A tourist group was headed by a tour guide. They were seen many times in an area. Which kind of group dynamics does this represent? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herd

 

A herd is a group of people with a leader whom they follow without questioning - like a political party leader being followed by party workers. In this case, the tourist group follows their tour guide without questioning, making it a classic example of herd behavior.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Crowd: Incorrect because a crowd is a temporary gathering of people who come together due to common interest without any leader or organization, like people gathering to watch a cricket match.

 

Option B. Band: Incorrect because a band is a community comprised of groups of families who not only live together but follow a certain pattern of life and culture.

 

Option D. Mob: Incorrect because while a mob has a leader, it is highly emotional, unstable, disorganized and sometimes acts against the law.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A group organized a mass gathering on handwashing awareness. Arrange the steps in the correct chronological sequence: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Awareness – Interest – Evaluation – Trial – Adoption 

 

When motivating a group to adopt a new practice like handwashing, there is a specific sequence of steps that follows the AITA principle:

 

  • Awareness - First, people need to be made aware that handwashing exists and is beneficial for health
  • Interest - Once aware, they develop interest in understanding how it benefits their health
  • Evaluation - They evaluate the information they've learned about handwashing
  • Trial - They try the practice of handwashing
  • Adoption - If found useful, they incorporate handwashing into their daily routine

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 The correct sequence for behavior change adoption in health education:

 

 Awareness → Interest → Evaluation → Trial → Adoption (AITA)

questions.text: It is being planned to put posters in the whole city for health promotion. Which type of health education approach is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mass based

 

Posters are a type of mass-based health education approach. Health education approaches can be divided into three main categories:

 

  • Individual-based methods (like interpersonal communication, personal letters, home visits)
  • Group-based methods (like lectures, focus group discussions, panel discussions)
  • Mass-based methods (like posters, television, radio, newsprint, banners, charts)

 

Posters placed throughout a city reach a large audience simultaneously and are therefore classified as a mass-based approach to health education.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Individual based: Incorrect as individual-based approaches involve one-on-one interactions like personal counseling or home visits 

 

Option B. Group-based: Incorrect as group-based approaches involve interactive sessions with specific groups like lectures or workshops 

 

Option D. One to one: Incorrect as this is a form of individual communication and not suitable for city-wide health promotion through posters

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Posters are a mass-based health education approach used for reaching large populations simultaneously with health messages.

 

Approaches For Health Communication

questions.text: Mr. X got married to Ms. Y in 1999. They had overall two children - Ms. M in 2002 and Ms. N in 2009. Mr. X’s father was a bank employee who moved in, post-retirement in 2008, with them along with his wife. Which stage of the family cycle do they belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Complete extension

 

The family cycle has 6 stages:

 

  • Formation: From marriage till first childbirth
  • Extension: From first childbirth till last childbirth
  • Complete extension: From last childbirth till first child leaves home
  • Contraction: From first child leaves home till last child leaves home
  • Complete contraction: From last child leaves home till death of first spouse
  • Dissolution: From death of first spouse till death of survivor

 

In this case:

 

  • Last childbirth (Ms. N) occurred in 2009
  • No children have left home yet
  • The family is therefore in the complete extension stage, which starts after last childbirth and continues until the first child leaves home

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete contraction: Incorrect as this stage occurs when all children have left home, which hasn't happened in this case

 

Option B. Extension: Incorrect as this stage is between first and last childbirth. The family has already had their last child in 2009

 

Option D. Dissolution: Incorrect as this stage occurs after death of first spouse, which hasn't happened in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Complete extension stage of family cycle starts after last childbirth and continues until first child leaves home.

 

Family system in INDIA

 

Family cycle

Combined OCPs are least protective for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Breast Ca

 

Combined OCPs provide protective effects against several gynecological conditions. However, they offer minimal to no protection against breast carcinoma. Combined OCPs are only protective against benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma, but not against breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. PID (Incorrect)

 

  • Combined OCPs provide significant protection against Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • The thickened cervical mucus and other mechanisms help prevent ascending infections

 

Option B. Endometrial Ca (Incorrect)

 

  • Combined OCPs offer strong protection against endometrial cancer
  • The hormonal effects help prevent endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent cancer risk

 

Option C. Ovarian Ca (Incorrect)

 

  • OCPs provide substantial protection against both benign and malignant ovarian diseases
  • The suppression of ovulation and other mechanisms contribute to this protective effect

 

Educational Objective:

 

While combined oral contraceptive pills provide protection against several gynecological conditions (PID, endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer), they do not provide significant protection against breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct reason for why f-IPV is preferred over OPV?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only OPV is associated with paralysis

 

The main reason for preferring fractionated IPV over OPV is that OPV has a significant risk of causing vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) and vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV). VAPP is specifically associated with poliovirus type 3, while VDPV is associated with poliovirus type 2 subtype C.  Injectable IPV, being an inactivated vaccine, does not carry this risk of paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IPV is more efficacious in combating epidemics: Incorrect. OPV is actually more useful in controlling epidemics due to its ability to provide intestinal immunity.

 

Option B. IPV is more cost-effective: Incorrect. OPV is actually more cost-effective compared to IPV.

 

Option C. IPV is simpler to administer: Incorrect. OPV is actually simpler to administer as it is given in the form of drops, while IPV requires injection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The key advantage of IPV over OPV is its safety profile, specifically the absence of risk of vaccine-associated paralytic polio (VAPP) and vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV).

questions.text: A patient is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following medications should be adjusted or stopped before the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stop Enalapril

 

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, should be stopped on the day of surgery because:

 

  • ACE inhibitors can cause refractory hypotension during surgery
  • This hypotension is resistant to fluid therapy and vasopressors
  • It occurs when the medication is taken within hours before surgery
  • The recommendation is to omit ACE inhibitors and ARBs on the morning of surgery

 

Other Options:

 

Options A & D. Aspirin: If taken in a prophylactic dose of 75 mg, it can be continued on the day of surgery. However, if taken in higher doses (150-300 mg), it increases the risk of surgical bleeding and should be stopped 3 days before surgery.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Beta-blockers are safe to continue as they help maintain stable hemodynamics during surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Before surgery, ACE inhibitors like Enalapril should be stopped due to the risk of refractory hypotension, while beta-blockers can be continued, and aspirin should be managed based on its dosage.

 

Hypertensive patients on Antihypertensives 

 

  1. ACE Inhibitors - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  2. Angiotensin receptor blockers - Omitted on day of surgery. 
  3. Diuretics - Continued on the day of surgery. 
  4. Beta Blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  5. Calcium channel blockers - Continue on the day of surgery. 
  6. Centrally acting alpha-2 agonists - Continue on the day of surgery. 

 

ANTICOAGULANTS 

 

  • Aspirin continued on day of surgery 
  • Clopidogrel - stopped 7 days prior to surgery 
  • Warfarin- stopped 5 days prior to surgery 
  • Heparin - stopped 4 hours prior to surgery 
  • LMWH-stopped 12 hours prior to surgery 
  • Ticlopidine - stopped 14 days prior to surgery 
  • BRIDGING DRUG - heparin.

questions.text: A doctor asks a patient about her age. The patient responds: "You know, doctor, I’m from a village. We were married at a very young age—at 12—with my husband, who is just 5 years older than me. Then, I had two kids when I was around 18 or something. Now, I look like their older sister. I’m just 32, doctor. "What is the thought disorder most likely displayed by the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Circumstantiality

 

This is a classic example of Circumstantiality, which refers to a pattern of speech in which the patient includes excessive and unnecessary details but eventually returns to the main point.

 

In this case, the patient eventually answers the doctor's question about her age but takes a long, indirect route with additional, unnecessary details about marriage, children,  appearance and returns to the main point.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tangentiality: Incorrect because in tangentiality, the patient never reaches the goal of thought. Here, the patient eventually stated her age (32 years), or in other words, reached the goal.

 

Option C. Derailment: Incorrect because in derailment, thoughts are not connected to each other. Here, though lengthy, the thoughts were connected (village life → marriage → children → current age).

 

Option D. Flight of ideas: Incorrect because flight of ideas involves rapid shifts between thoughts based on chance connections, often with pressured speech. Here, the speech wasn't rapid, and connections weren't based on chance but followed a logical (though unnecessarily detailed) progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thought Disorders

A 22-year-old man, diagnosed with Crohn’s disease, presents with persistent diarrhea for the past 3 months following ileal resection for small-bowel obstruction. He reports 4-5 loose bowel movements daily, significantly disrupting his daily activities and studies. He denies fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, or weight loss.

 

He had a perianal abscess treated with metronidazole 7 months ago. Physical examination is unremarkable, apart from a well-healed abdominal scar.

 

Laboratory findings:

 

  • Mild anemia (Hb: 12.0 g/dL)
  • Hypokalemia (K+: 3.4 mEq/L)
  • Normal ESR (10 mm/h)
  • Normal B12 levels

 

Which of the following is most likely to improve his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cholestyramine

 

  • This patient has post-ileal resection diarrhea, most likely due to bile acid malabsorption. 
  • The terminal ileum is responsible for reabsorbing bile salts, and when resected, excess bile acids enter the colon, leading to secretory diarrhea and irritation of the colonic mucosa.
  • Cholestyramine (a bile acid sequestrant) binds excess bile acids, preventing their colonic irritation and reducing diarrhea.
  • The ileocecal valve sparing suggests mild/moderate bile acid loss, making cholestyramine highly effective.
  • B12 deficiency is not yet present but may develop over time due to impaired absorption in the terminal ileum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: Post-surgical diarrhea here is not related to lactose intolerance as he has no history of bloating or dairy-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Mesalamine: Used for mild Crohn’s colitis, but not effective for post-ileal resection bile acid diarrhea.

 

Option D. Prednisone: Indicated for acute Crohn’s disease flares, but this patient has no inflammatory symptoms (abdominal pain, fever, or high ESR), so steroids are unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bile acid malabsorption is a common cause of chronic diarrhea following ileal resection, as the terminal ileum plays a crucial role in bile salt reabsorption. 
  • Excess bile acids in the colon lead to secretory diarrhea, which can significantly impact daily life. 
  • Cholestyramine, a bile acid sequestrant, effectively binds bile acids and alleviates symptoms. 
  • Early recognition and appropriate management are essential to improving quality of life in post-resection patients.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with schizophrenia had been compliant with her prescribed olanzapine for several months. However, she discontinued the treatment. Which of the following is the most likely reason for her discontinuation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Weight gain

 

Olanzapine is known to cause significant weight gain and metabolic side effects. In fact, among atypical antipsychotics, olanzapine causes the second-highest weight gain (after clozapine). This metabolic side effect is often a major reason for treatment discontinuation in patients, especially young women who may be concerned about body image and health implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tardive dyskinesia (TD): Incorrect because atypical antipsychotics like olanzapine have a very low propensity for causing tardive dyskinesia compared to typical antipsychotics. Olanzapine in particular has a very low propensity for TD.

 

Option C. Acute dystonia: Incorrect because acute dystonia is usually caused by typical antipsychotics, particularly with parenteral administration. It is unlikely with olanzapine.

 

Option D. Akathisia: Incorrect because among atypical antipsychotics, aripiprazole is more likely to cause akathisia. Olanzapine is not particularly associated with this side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weight gain is a significant side effect of olanzapine (second highest among atypical antipsychotics after clozapine) and is often a major reason for treatment non-compliance, especially in young patients.
